bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, Albert G. Love, and J.F. Siler, October 28, 1952

div1.p: Hench regrets that Dean and perhaps Pinto will not be mentioned at the dedication ceremony. However, he is delighted that Kean, Truby, Sternberg and Ames will be honored. Hench approves the recommendation to increase the pension for Blossom Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, Albert G. Love, and J.F. Siler, October 28, 1952
div1.opener:
October 28, 1952
General Albert Truby
General Albert Love
Colonel J. F. Siler
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
I have received the enclosed letter from Dr. Pedro Nogueira. I have sent my
general approval. Unfortunately my reply was delayed because of several out-
of-town meetings. It would hardly seem proper for me to make any belated changes.
As you know, in July I sent him a series of documented reports and very specific
suggestions. Now that they have gone over them, it hardly seems proper for me
to do more than give him my general approval. On the other hand, it may not be
too late, if you have a real objection to any of his decisions, for you to cable
him.

I am sorry that Dean and perhaps Doctor Pinto will not be mentioned. Certainly
Dean might be mentioned, but they seem to be confining the names to those who
actually served at Camp Lazear and if so, Dean gets left out. I am of course
delighted that they are honoring Generals Kean and Truby and Sternberg and
Doctor Ames. It is also, I suppose, fitting that Lambert who nursed most of
the men so assiduously, should also be honored. He was certainly the main
male nurse.

To what extent Miss Warner deserves this honor, I am not certain. I think she
was the woman nurse who nursed Lazear and perhaps three or four of the earlier
cases, but I am a little prejudiced against her because I have read an article
or two that she wrote which contained many inaccuracies. I do not know enough
however to object. If General Truby does, I shall have to leave that to him.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: General Truby: I fly to New York today and then to Boston but will be
back Friday morning. Look what greeted me in the morning Minneapolis paper. Who
in the world is John Peter Barstad? I never heard of him. Can you tell me who
he was? I didn't realize that Minneapolis had its own “pretender.” Incidentally,
the number of old Spanish American War veterans who “remember” all about their
contribution to Walter Reed is large enough to fill a regiment.
I know the medical editor of the Minneapolis Tribune and if you give me the dope
or if you can get it somewhere, I will quietly tip him off so that they will not
make this mistake again without a little investigation. Of course it is no use
for me to correct this publicly. That would be more offensive than useful.
P.S.: I heartily approve your suggestion that the amount of income for Blossom
Reed be increased.
